turns.speaker: MANOLO
turns.text: A group of us are going out tonight.

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: MANOLO
turns.text: Guzman, Tomas, Esteban --

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: Your new friends.

turns.speaker: MANOLO
turns.text: Yeah.  It should be fun.  You wanna come?

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: Not this time.

turns.speaker: MANOLO
turns.text: It's no problem.  I was just with everybody we work with.

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: Oh, really.  General Salazar was there?

turns.speaker: MANOLO
turns.text: No, but a lot of other people.  You should come.  You should come out with us.

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: Go home.  Get cleaned up.  Get to work.  Salazar is heading down to Mexico City next week and I'm not getting left behind.  Don't fuck this up.

turns.speaker: MANOLO
turns.text: Madrigal's alive.

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MANOLO
turns.text: Porfirio Madrigal is not dead.  I just saw him.

turns.speaker: MANOLO
turns.text: Javi!  Come on.  Don't pull this you don't care bullshit.  This is incredible information.  It must be. Javi --

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: We keep our mouths shut.

turns.speaker: JOHNSON
turns.text: Somewhere safe.

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: JOHNSON
turns.text: A place we have, that we know is protected.

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: It's important that we work together. Mexico.  America.  One hand washing the other.

turns.speaker: JOHNSON
turns.text: We agree.

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: So... maybe you tell me about your informants in our operations.

turns.speaker: JOHNSON
turns.text: We thought maybe you'd have that kind of information for us.

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: This is a very different proposition.

turns.speaker: JOHNSON
turns.text: You should feel good about this.

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: I feel like a traitor.

turns.speaker: SALAZAR
turns.text: What's your name?

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: Javier Rodriguez.

turns.speaker: SALAZAR
turns.text: Well, Javier Rodriguez, you've done a very good job, but we'll take care of it from here.

turns.speaker: SALAZAR
turns.text: One question.  How did you find about this?

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: An informant.

turns.speaker: SALAZAR
turns.text: What is the name of your informant?

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: It was an anonymous tip.

turns.speaker: SALAZAR
turns.text: That's your past.  I want to talk about your future.  Would you be willing to do something for me?

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: If I can.

turns.speaker: SALAZAR
turns.text: I'm trying to bust the Tijuana Cartel.

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: What is it you want me to do?

turns.speaker: SALAZAR
turns.text: A small thing.  Nothing really.

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: Does this offer include my partner?

turns.speaker: SALAZAR
turns.text: Only if he can be trusted.

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: He'll do what I say.

turns.speaker: SALAZAR
turns.text: I'm curious how you did this with such economy.

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: Everybody has a weakness.

turns.speaker: SALAZAR
turns.text: You watch and learn.  I earn his trust.  Then more pain.  Then I appear with kindness.  Within a week he will follow me around like a dog.

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: But will he be house-trained?

turns.speaker: SALAZAR
turns.text: When he loves me like a father, he will never tell anyone he was here. He will freely give the names of his superiors.  Then we get them and they too will give us names.  And eventually somebody will get us to Juan Obregon and the cartel will fall.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: The cocaine brand, 911, is an East Coast brand, a Juarez Cartel brand, and you must know it usually comes through into El Paso?

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: I'm aware of that.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: So what's it doing in Tijuana?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Let me ask you a hypothetical question: if Salazar worked for Madrigal and the Juaraz cartel, and he went out of power, would it mean the Juarez Cartel is losing influence?

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: It could mean that, yes.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: That would probably mean the Tijuana Cartel is gaining power?

turns.speaker: JAVIER
turns.text: It's possible.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Is it possible to have a Drug Czar in Mexico who isn't connected in some war to one of the cartels?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: My work keeps me young.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Which part, getting terrorists loose on bail or freeing convicted murderers on technicalities?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: The worst serial killer in history - who?  Gacy - right?  Killed forty two people.  Our government killed fifty thousand in Vietnam and lied about it every day.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Michael, you represent drug dealers, not civil libertarians.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: We kidnapped Noriega out of Panama. Is that covered in your Constitution? Because it isn't in mine.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Noriega is a criminal.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Noriega was head of a sovereign nation who made the mistake of doing business with the U.S.  Government.  So, no, I don't have a problem waking up every day and fighting our government, fighting people like you, trying to keep this system a little bit honest.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Last I read your clients were chopping people up with chainsaws and delivering illegal narcotics into this country.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I hope when you were on the bench, Judge Wakefield, you didn't handle the presumption of innocence in the same fashion.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: If I ever return to the bench, Counselor Adler, I hope I have the pleasure of hearing your arguments.

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: The busiest land border crossing in the world.  Over forty-one thousand vehicles per day, twenty-two thousand pedestrians on foot.  I think we do a pretty good job but we know a lot of drugs are still getting through.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Any idea how much?

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: I've read official estimates but I wouldn't bet my house on them.  I've heard the entire cocaine supply for the United States can fit into four tractor-trailers.  At least a half-dozen of those cars right out there are carrying a load of dope, with drivers employed by people who don't give a damn if they're caught or not.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: What do you look for?

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: We ask questions and measure the answers.  When something doesn't ring true, a fact that doesn't make sense, a slight hesitation, then it's off to secondary for a closer look.  Before NAFTA we had about 1.9 million trucks a year.  Now it's almost double.  Pretty soon there'll be Mexican truck companies that will have as much freedom in crossing the border as American truck companies.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Any way we can do it better?

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: Sure.  More money in intelligence on their side of the border.  So we have a better idea who we're looking for.  More dogs.  More people. Supposed to be getting some giant x- ray machines to run the trucks through.  Outside of martial law that's about the best you're gonna do.  But, I should tell you, there are two things that really have us on edge right now.  In the last six months seizures have tripled, even though we're pulling over the same number of cars.  What does that tell you?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: That triple the amount of stuff is going through.

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: Right.  But, that's not the biggest problem.  One of our Intel officers picked up information from DEA that traffickers have come up with a process, a chemical process, to turn coke into something else.  It doesn't smell like coke.  It doesn't look like coke.  And what's worse, it doesn't react to field test.  It could be anything.  Maybe it's already happening.  I mean, how would we know?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I'm looking for my daughter, Caroline. She comes here.

turns.speaker: SKETCH
turns.text: This is a business.  Get the fuck outta here.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I need to find my daughter.  I'll pay you.

turns.speaker: SKETCH
turns.text: Who the fuck do you think you are? Where the fuck do you think you are? Why the fuck do you think I shouldn't just put you in a dumpster?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I have money --

turns.speaker: SKETCH
turns.text: I got money.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I'll pay you a thousand dollars.  I have it in my wallet.

turns.speaker: SKETCH
turns.text: I want your money, I'll take your money.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Just tell me where she is.

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: She's not at that place you sent her?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: She snuck away.  And we haven't seen her.  She hasn't come home.

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: Oh, man --

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: She hasn't called you?

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: I tried to talk to her when she was up there, but they wouldn't put me through.  I'm surprised she hasn't called.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Can you tell me anything?  Do you have any ideas?

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: I don't know what to say.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I'm not the police.  I don't care about experimentation.  She's a kid. I'm worried to death.

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: You won't say anything to my parents?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I don't give a fuck about your parents --

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: We sometimes went downtown to score.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: The West End.  We buy it off the streets.  I can stop, you know, and she can't. Two people, really similar, we can talk about anything, but for me it's like a weekend thing, then I get my shit together, and for her it's different --

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You don't know what the hell you're talking about.  You're a cocky seventeen year-old and you don't have a clue what the stakes are. You don't know the value of the life you've yet to throw away.  And neither does she.

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: Hey man, I'm sorry.  I'm just trying to help.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You want to help?  Stay the fuck away from her.

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: I don't know, maybe we missed her.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I can't believe you used to bring my daughter here, to this place.

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: Hey man, back the fuck up.  To this place.  What's that shit?  Right now, all over this country, a hundred thousand white people from the suburbs are driving around downtown asking every black person they see, You got any drugs?  You know where I can get drugs?  What kind of effect you think this has on the psyche of a black person, on their possibilities?  If you sent a hundred thousand black people into your neighborhood, Indian Hills, and they asked every white person they saw, hey, you got any drugs?, within a day, your friends and their kids would be selling. It's market forces, man.  The product's marked up three hundred percent.  You can go out on the street and make five hundred bucks in two hours and then do whatever you want for the rest of the day.  You think white people would still be going to law school?

turns.speaker: SALAZAR
turns.text: I recruited the best men in Mexico for my task force and put them through a rigorous screening process.  Not only physical, but also psychological.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I'd like to bring you up to Washington, walk you around our side of things, and share some of the information we've been able to develop on your cartels.

turns.speaker: SALAZAR
turns.text: That would be very helpful to me.  Also, I received the offer from DEA and the FBI to train some of my men at Quantico.  I think this will be extremely useful, a good way for us to absorb some of your methods.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You've been making very good progress against the Tijuana cartel.

turns.speaker: SALAZAR
turns.text: Yes, I am confident that Juan Obregon will be taken into custody before the end of the year.  But, you must understand that it is very difficult because of corruption in the police force.  We get a tip that he is one place, then we get there and he is already gone, having been warned by someone on our side.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Hopefully the exchange of training methods and information between our countries will help with this problem.

turns.speaker: SALAZAR
turns.text: Yes, I hope so as well.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Let me ask you a related question. We've talked about the supply side, but what about demand?  What is your policy for treating addiction?

turns.speaker: SALAZAR
turns.text: Addicts treat themselves... they overdose and then there's one less to worry about.

turns.speaker: SHERIDAN
turns.text: I just want to be clear about one thing.  I used to work for him, but now I work for you.  I'm not a partisan person, I'm an issue person. In the next few weeks, if you allow me, we'll get you well-versed on an incredible array of issues.  The most important of which, in my opinion, being Mexico.  I know everybody that you're gonna meet. It's important that they like you. It's not important that they like me.  That's why I can help protect you.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Like you protected Landry?

turns.speaker: SHERIDAN
turns.text: I see where you're going with that, but if I could just say something, which is basically that a guy like Landry is so autocratic he doesn't know how to let himself be helped; it's a point of pride to take every bullet, no matter who fired it, or whether it was even aimed at him, which personally I think it very self-defeating.  Now, don't get me wrong, he's a man of enormous integrity, but there's a political component to this job that the General just didn't have any patience for.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: SHERIDAN
turns.text: I'm sorry... Did I wake you?

turns.speaker: SHERIDAN
turns.text: Salazar's been taken down.  He was working for Porfirio Madrigal.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: What?  I thought Madrigal was dead. I thought it was verified.

turns.speaker: SHERIDAN
turns.text: Apparently not.  Look, it's a shit storm here right now.  When are you coming back?  I don't know what to tell people any more.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I'll get there as soon as I can.

turns.speaker: SHERIDAN
turns.text: If we're moving the press conference, we need to do it now.  Are you all right?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Who are these guys?

turns.speaker: SPECIAL-AGENT-IN-CHARGE
turns.text: Agents who died in the field.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: He died in a liposuction surgery, right?

turns.speaker: SPECIAL-AGENT-IN-CHARGE
turns.text: Right.  Now it's used by somebody from the Juarez Cartel, one of his lieutenants...  Who knows?  Every damn day there's birthday party. At first I thought they must have three hundred children, then I realized they're taunting us.  Three miles away and we can't touch them. Ha, ha, ha.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Who do we interface with on their side?

turns.speaker: SPECIAL-AGENT-IN-CHARGE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I mean, who runs interdiction on the Mexico side?

turns.speaker: SPECIAL-AGENT-IN-CHARGE
turns.text: I don't know.  I don't think there's any one person.  See the problem is the Juarez cartel owns everything and everybody, all the property on the Mexican side, sometimes all the property on both sides.  Warehouses, transportation, even tunnels.  It's very organized.

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: What do we do?  Okay.  Fucked-up Bowman's turning blue.  Doctor.  We need a doctor.

turns.speaker: VANESSA
turns.text: Your dad's a doctor.  Call him --

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: He's a research doctor.  You're dad's a doctor, too --

turns.speaker: VANESSA
turns.text: What kind of research?

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: Mapping the fucking pig genome. We'll call your dad, he's a neurosurgeon --

turns.speaker: VANESSA
turns.text: It's three a.m.  I'm not supposed to be here.  I snuck out --

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Did you tell him?

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: No. On you go.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: The cards. The last thing I said to you was mind the cards.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Well, I've not brought them.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: It's fucking boring after a while without the cards.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Well, I've not brought them.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: It's fucking boring after a while without the cards.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: Bit fucking late, like.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Well, why didn't you bring them?

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: Because I fucking told you to do that, you doss cunt.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Christ.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: OK. Same again?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: I'm off for a pish. When I come back, that money's still here, OK?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: I'll be right after you.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: You'll never catch us, you flabby bastard. Right, see, when I come back --

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: I want the money, Mark, that's all.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: If everyone keeps their mouth shut, there'll be no one going to jail.

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: I don't know, maybe I'll buy something for my ma, and then buy some good speed, no bicarb like, then get a girl, take her out like, and treat her -- properly.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: Shag her senseless.

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: No, I don't mean like that -- I mean something nice, like, that's all --

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: You daft cunt. If you're going to waste it like that, you might as well leave it all to me. Now get the drinks in.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: Shut you mouth or you'll be next.

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: You've stabbed me, man.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: You were in my way.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: Twenty thousand.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: But it's not worth more than fifteen.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: Ninteen.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: For fuck's sake.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Sorry, mate, I'll get you another.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: All down my fucking front, you fucking idiot.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Look, I'm sorry, I didn't mean it.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: Sorry's no going to dry me off, you cunt.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: And remember, Rents: no skag.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Aye, OK, Fr.  But the good times couldn't last for ever.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: It's a scandal, Franco.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: Too right it is. Now look, have you got anything to eat, 'cos I'm fucking Lee Marvin, by the way.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: I've no fucking cigarettes.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: Hey, I'm wanting a bet put on.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Can you not go yourself.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: I'm a fugitive from the law. I can't be seen on the fucking streets. Now watch my lips. Kempton Park. Two-thirty. Five pounds to win. Bad Boy.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: I'm no a fucking buftie and that's the end of it.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Let's face it, it could have been wonderful.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: Yes, you fucking do. I've seen your statement.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Jesus.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: Two thousand, one hundred and thirty- three pounds.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Four kilos. That's what -- Ten years' worth? Russian sailors? Mikey Forrester? What the fuck are you on these days? You've been to jail, Spud, so what's the deal -- like it so much you want to go back again?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: This was his nightmare. The dodgiest scam in a lifetime of dodgie scams being perpetrated with three of the most useless and unreliable fuck-ups in town. I knew what was going on in his mind: any trouble in London and he would dump us immediately, one way or another. He had to. If he got caught with a bagful of skag, on top of that armed robbery shit, he was going down for fifteen to twenty. Begbie was hard, but not so hard that he didn't shite it off twenty years in Saughton.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: Did you bring the cards?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Buy yourself that island in the sun?

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: For four fucking grand?  One palm tree, a couple of rocks, and a sewage outflow.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: We'll be half-way down the road with the money.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: I'd fucking kill you.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: I guess you would, Franco.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Cool down, Franco. The guy's sorry.

turns.speaker: BEGBIE
turns.text: Not sorry enough for being a fat cunt.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Excuse me, I don't mean to harass you, but I was very impressed by the capable and stylish manner in which you dealt with that situation. I thought to myself: she's special.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: What's your name?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Diane.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Where are you going, Diane?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I'm going home.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Where's that?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: It's where I live.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: I'll come back if you like, but I'm not promising anything.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Do you find that this approach usually works, or, let me guess, you've never tried it before. In fact, you don't normally approach girls, am I right? The truth is that you're a quite, sensitive type but if I'm prepared to take a chance I might just get to know the inner you: witty, adventurous, passionate, loving, loyal, a little bit crazy, a little bit bad, but, hey, don't us girls just love that?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Eh-

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Well, what's wrong, boy? Cat got your tongue.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: think I left something back at the -

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Diane.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Ssshh!

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Shut up.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Christ, I haven't felt that good since Archie Gemmill scored against Holland in 1978.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Right. You can't sleep here.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Out.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Come on.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: No argument. You can sleep on the sofa in the living room, or go home. It's up to you.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Jesus.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: And don't make any noise.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I don't see why not.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Because it's illegal.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Holding hands?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: No, not holding hands.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: In that case you can do it. You were quite happy to do a lot more last night.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: And that's what's illegal. Do you know what they do to people like me inside? They'd cut my balls off and flush them down the fucking toilet.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Calm down. You're not going to jail.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Easy for you to say.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Can I see you again?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Certainly not.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Are you clean?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Is that a promise, then?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Yes, as a matter of fact, it is.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Calm down, I'm just asking. Is that hash I can smell?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I wouldn't mind a bit, if it is.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Well, it isn't.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Smells like it.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: You're too young.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Too young for what?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You're not getting any younger, Mark. The world is changing, music is changing, even drugs are changing. You can't stay in here all day dreaming about heroin and Ziggy Pop.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: It's Iggy Pop.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Whatever. I mean, the guy's dead anyway.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Iggy Pop is not dead. He toured last year. Tommy went to see him.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: The point is, you've got to find something new.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: It's so simple. We buy it at four grand, we punt it at twenty to this guy that Sick Boy knows, and he punts it at sixty. Everyone's happy, everyone's in profit. I put up two. I come away with six.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Unless you get caught.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: So long as everyone keeps their mouths shut, we'll not be getting caught.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: So why have you told me about it?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Well, you're not going to tell anyone, are you, and besides, I thought we could meet up afterwards, maybe go somewhere together.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I've got a boyfriend, Mark.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: What? Steady like?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: That's right: 'going steady' for four weeks now.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: And what age are you? Thirteen? Fourteen?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Sixteen next month.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Happy birthday.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: What do you think -- I should be carrying a torch for you?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: So, what's he like?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Well, he's young and he's healthy.

turns.speaker: GAIL
turns.text: I read it in Cosmopolitan.

turns.speaker: LIZZY
turns.text: It's an interesting theory.

turns.speaker: GAIL
turns.text: Actually it's a nightmare. I've been desperate for a shag, but watching him suffer was just too much fun. You should try it with Tommy.

turns.speaker: LIZZY
turns.text: What, and deny myself the only pleasure I get from him? Did I tell you about my birthday?

turns.speaker: GAIL
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: LIZZY
turns.text: He forgot. Useless motherfucker.

turns.speaker: GAV
turns.text: Tommy knew he had the virus, like, but never knew he'd gone full-blown.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: What was it, pneumonia or cancer?

turns.speaker: GAV
turns.text: No, toxoplasmosis. Sort of like a stroke.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Eh? How's that?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: I bet Lizzy told him where to put it.

turns.speaker: GAV
turns.text: Exactly. I'm not wanting a cat, she says. Get to fuck, right. So there's Tommy stuck with this kitten. You can imagine what happened. The thing was neglected, pissing and shitting all over the place. Tommy was lying around fucked out of his eyeballs on smack or downers. He didn't know you could get toxoplasmosis from cat shit.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: I didn't either. What the fuck is it?

turns.speaker: LIZZY
turns.text: Tommy, let's put the tape on.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Now?

turns.speaker: LIZZY
turns.text: Yes, I want to watch ourselves while we're screwing.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Fuck, OK.

turns.speaker: LIZZY
turns.text: What do you mean, it's 'gone'? Where has it gone, Tommy?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: It'll be here somewhere. I might have returned it by mistake.

turns.speaker: LIZZY
turns.text: Returned it? Where? To the video shop, Tommy? To the fucking video store? So every punter in Edinburgh is jerking off to our video? God, Tommy, I feel sick.

turns.speaker: MAN 1
turns.text: Well, Mr. Renton, I see that you attended the Royal Edinburgh College.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Indeed, yes, those halcyon days.

turns.speaker: MAN 1
turns.text: One of Edinburgh's finest schools.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Oh, yes, indeed. I look back on my time there with great fondness and affection. The debating society, the first eleven, the soft know of willow on leather --

turns.speaker: MAN 1
turns.text: I'm an old boy myself, you know?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Oh, really?

turns.speaker: MAN 1
turns.text: Do you recall the school motto?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Of course, the motto, the motto --

turns.speaker: MAN 1
turns.text: Strive, hope, believe and conquer.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Exactly. Those very words have been my guiding light in what is, after all, a dark and often hostile world.

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: No, actually I went to Craignewton but I was worried that you wouldn't have heard of it so I put the Royal Edinburgh College instead, because they're both schools, right, and we're all in this together, and I wanted to put across the general idea rather than the details, yeah? People get all hung up on details, but what's the point? Like which school? Does it matter? Why? When? Where? Or how many O grades did I get? Could be six, could be one, but that's not important. What's important is that I am, right? That I am.

turns.speaker: MAN 1
turns.text: Mr. Murphy, do you mean that you lied on your application?

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: Only to get my foot in the door. Showing initiative, right?

turns.speaker: MAN 1
turns.text: You were referred here by the Department of Employment. There's no need for you to get you "foot in the door", as you put it.

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: Hey. Right. No problem. Whatever you say, man. You're the man, the governor, the dude in the chair, like. I'm merely here. But obviously I am. Here, that is. I hope I'm not talking too much. I don't usually. I think it's all important though, isn't it?

turns.speaker: MAN 1
turns.text: Thank you, Mr. Murphy. We'll let you know.

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: The pleasure was mine. Best interview I've ever been to. Thanks.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Morning, Spud. Sit down and have some breakfast.

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: Sorry about last night -

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I'll put the sheets in the washing machine just now.

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: No, I'll wash them. I'll take them home and bring them back.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: There's no need.

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: It's no problem.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: No problem for me either.  Honestly, it's no problem.

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: I'd really rather take care of it myself.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Spud, they're my sheets.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Are you getting out much?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Following the game at all?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: No. Me Neither.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: You take the test?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Aye.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Clear?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Aye.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: That's nice.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: I'm sorry, Tommy.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Have you got any gear on you?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: No, I'm clean.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Well, sub us, then, mate. I'm expecting a rent cheque.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Thanks, Mark.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: No problem.  No problem -- easy to say when its some other poor cunt with shite for blood.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Good luck, Spud.

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: Cheers.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Now remember --

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: If they think you're not trying, you're in trouble. First hint of that, they'll be on to the DSS, 'This cunt's no trying' and your Giro is fucking finished, right?

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: But try too hard --

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: And you might get the fucking job.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Exactly.

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: Nightmare.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: It's a tightrope, Spud, a fucking tightrope.

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: My problem is that I tend to clam up. I go dumb and I can't answer any questions at all. Nerves on the big occasion, like a footballer.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Try this.

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: A little too well, if anything, a little too well, that's my only fear, compadre.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Another dab?

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: Would not say no, would not say no.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: I chose not to choose life: I chose something else. And the reasons? There are no reasons. Who need reasons when you've got heroin?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Goldfinger's better than Dr. No. Both of them are a lot better than Diamonds are Forever a judgement reflected in its relative poor showing at the box office, in which field, of course, Thunderball was a notable success.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: People think it's all about misery and desperation and death and all that shite, which is not to be ignored, but what they forget - Spud is shooting up for the pleasure of it. Otherwise we wouldn't do it. After all, we're not fucking stupid. At least, we're not that fucking stupid. Take the best orgasm you ever had, multiply it by a thousand and you're still nowhere near it. When you're on junk you have only one worry: scoring. When you're off it you are suddenly obliged to worry about all sorts of other shite. Got no money: can't get pished. Got money: drinking too much. Can't get a bird: no chance of a ride. Got a bird: too much hassle. You have to worry about bills, about food, about some football team that never fucking wins, about human relationships and all the things that really don't matter when you've got a sincere and truthful junk habit.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: I would say, in those days, he was a muscular actor, in every sense, with all the presence of someone like Cooper or Lancaster, but combined with a sly wit to make him a formidable romantic lead, closer in that respect to Cary Grant.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: The only drawback, or at least the principal drawback, is that you have to endure all manner of cunts telling you that -

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: You Only Live Twice?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Nineteen-sixty-seven.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Running time?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: One hundred and sixteen minutes.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Director?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Lewis Gilbert.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Screenwriter?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Eh - Ian Fleming?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Fuck off! He never wrote any of them.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: OK, so who was it, then?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: You can look it up.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Who wrote it?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: But you're looking better, it has to be said. Healthier. Radiant even.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: You don't know, do you?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: And I wondered if you'd care to go to the park tomorrow.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: The park?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Tomorrow afternoon. Usual set-up.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Who wrote it?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Roald Dahl.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Roald Dahl. Fuck me.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: It's certainly a phenomenon in all walks of life.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Well, at one time, you've got it, and then you lose it, and it's gone for ever. All walks of life: George Best, for example, had it and lost it, or David Bowie, or Lou Reed -

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Some of his solo stuff's not bad.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: No, it's not bad, but it's not great either, is it? And in your heart you kind of know that although it sounds all right, it's actually just shite.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: So who else?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Charlie Nicholas, David Niven, Malcolm McLaren, Elvis Presley. -

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: OK, OK, so what's the point you're trying to make?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: All I'm trying to do is help you understand that The Name of the Rose is merely a blip on an otherwise uninterrupted downward trajectory.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: What about The Untouchables?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: I don't rate that at all.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Despite the Academy award?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: That means fuck all. The sympathy vote.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Right. So we all get old and then we can't hack it any more. Is that it?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: That's your theory?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Yeah, Beautifully fucking illustrated.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Give me the gun.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Do you see the beast? Have you got it in you sights?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Clear enough, Moneypenny. This should present no significant problem.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: I think Allison had been screaming all day, but it hadn't really registered before. She might have been screaming for a week for all I knew. It's been days since I've heard anyone speak, though surely someone must have said something in all that time, surely to fuck someone must have.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: What's wrong, Allison?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Oh, fuck. Sick Boy reaches out to Allison.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: It wasn't my baby. She wasn't my baby. Baby Dawn. She wasn't mine. Spud's? Swanney's? Sick Boy's? I don't know. Maybe Allison knew. Maybe not. I wished I could think of something to say, something sympathetic, something human.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Say something, Mark, say something --

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: I'm cooking' up. There is a silence.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Eughh. Sounds horrible.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: It wasn't that bad.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Did he -- you know?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: You know.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: No, he didn't make me touch it.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Oh no, don't even mention it.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: He made me lick it.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: God, you're sick.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: And I got a stitch stuck between my teeth, jerked my head back and the whole fucking stump fell off.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Cut it out.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: When are you going to visit him?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Don't know. Maybe Thursday.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: You're a real mate. And what about Tommy? Have you been to see him yet?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Fuck you. OK, so Tommy's got the virus. Bad news, big deal. The gig goes on, or hadn't you noticed? Swanney fucks his leg up. Well, tough shit, but it could have been worse.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: You're all hear.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: I know a couple of addicts. Stupid wee lassies. I feed them what they need. A little bit of skag to keep them happy while the punters line up at a fiver a skull. It's easy money for me. Not exactly a fortune, but I'm thinking, 'I should be coining it here.'  Less whores, more skag. Swanney's right. Get clean, get into dealing, that's where the future lies. Set up some contacts, get a good load of skag, punt it, profit. What do you think?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Fuck you.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: And I'll tell you why. Because I'm fed up to my back teeth with losers, no-hopers, draftpacks, schemies, junkies and the like. I'm getting on with life. What are you doing?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: I can't believe you did that.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: I got a good price for it. Rents, I need the money.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: It was my fucking television.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Well, Christ, if I'd known you were going to get so humpty about it, I wouldn't have bothered. Are you going to eat that?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Well, this guy I've met runs a hotel. Brother. Loads of contacts. Does a nice little sideline in punting British passports to foreigners. Get you a good price.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Why would I want to sell my passport?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: It was just an idea.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: There's a mate of swanney's. Mikey Forrester -- you know the guy. He's come into some gear. A lot of gear.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: How much?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: About four kilos. So he tells me. Got drunk in a pub down by the docks last week, where he met two Russian sailors. They're fucking carrying the stuff. For sale there and then, like. So he wakes up the next morning, realizes what he's done and get very fucking nervous. Wants rid of this. {---------- He's looking for Swanney to punt it, but Swanney's nowhere to be seen since he lost his leg. ---------- }

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: So he met me and I offered to take it off his hands at a very reasonable price, with the intention of punting it on myself to a guy I know in London.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: So we've just come from Tommy's funeral and you're telling me about a skag deal?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: What was your price?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Four Grand.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: But you don't have the money?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: We're two thousand short.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: That's tough.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Come on, Mark, every cunt knows you've been saving up down in London.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Sorry, boys, I don't have two thousand pounds.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: From time to time, even I have uttered the magic words.

turns.speaker: SWANNEY
turns.text: Are you serious?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Yeah. No more. I'm finished with that shite.

turns.speaker: SWANNEY
turns.text: Well, it's up to you.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: I'm going to get it right this time. Going to get it set up and get off it for good.

turns.speaker: SWANNEY
turns.text: Sure, sure. I've heard it before.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: The Sick Boy method.

turns.speaker: SWANNEY
turns.text: Yeah, well, it surely worked for him.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: He's always been lacking in moral fibre.

turns.speaker: SWANNEY
turns.text: He knows a lot about Sean Connery.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: That's hardly a substitute.

turns.speaker: SWANNEY
turns.text: you'll need one more hit.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: No, I don't think so.

turns.speaker: SWANNEY
turns.text: To see you through the night that lies ahead.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: What's on the menu this evening?

turns.speaker: SWANNEY
turns.text: Your favourite dish.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Excellent.

turns.speaker: SWANNEY
turns.text: Your usual table, sir?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Why, thank you.

turns.speaker: SWANNEY
turns.text: And would sir care to settle his bill in advance?

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Stick it on my tab.

turns.speaker: SWANNEY
turns.text: Regret to inform, sir, that your credit limit was reached and breached a long time ago.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: In that case --

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: No, thank you. I'll proceed directly to the intravenous injection of hard drugs, please.

turns.speaker: SWANNEY
turns.text: As you wish.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: SWANNEY
turns.text: And see when I get out of here. I've got plans. Going to get myself straightened out and head off to Thailand, where women really know how to treat a guy. See, out there you can live like a king if you've got white skin and a few crisp tenners in your pocket. No fucking problem.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: SWANNEY
turns.text: The strategy is this: get clean, get mobile, get into dealing, and this time next year I'll be watching the rising sun with a posse of oriental buttocks parked on my coupon.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: Sounds great, Swanney.

turns.speaker: SWANNEY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: RENTON
turns.text: You'll have to send us a postcard.

turns.speaker: SWANNEY
turns.text: Sure will, pal, sure will.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: This had better be good.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: It will be. It'll make a change for three miserable junkies who don't know what they want to do with themselves since they stopped doing smack.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: If I'm giving up a whole day and the price of a ticket, I'm just saying it had better be good. There's plenty of other things I could be doing.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Such as?

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Such as sitting in a darkened room, watching videos, drinking, smoking dope and wanking. Does that answer your question?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: There.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Are you serious?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: It's the great outdoors.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: It's really nice, Tommy. Can we go home now?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: It's fresh air.

turns.speaker: SICK BOY
turns.text: Look, Tommy, we know you're getting a hard time off Lizzy, but there's no need to take it out on us.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Doesn't it make you proud to be Scottish?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: How's it going with Gail?

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: No joy yet.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: How long is it?

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: Six weeks.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Six weeks!

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: It's a nightmare. She told me she didn't want our relationship to start on a physical basis as that is how it would be principally defined from then on in.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Where did she come up with that?

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: She read it in Cosmopolitan.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Six weeks and no sex?

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: I've got balls like watermelons, I'm telling you.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Useless motherfucker, that's what she called me. I told her, I'm sorry, but theses things happen. Let's put it behind us.

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: That's fair enough.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Yes, but then she finds out I've bought a ticket for Iggy Pop the same night.

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: Went ballistic?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Big time. Absolutely fucking radge. 'It's me or Iggy Pop, time to decide.'

turns.speaker: SPUD
turns.text: So what's it going to be?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Well, I've paid for the ticket.
